Contentious material about living persons that is unsourced or poorly sourced **must be removed immediately** from the article and its talk page, especially if potentially libelous. *Find sources:* "Lim Swee Say" – news **·** newspapers **·** books **·** scholar **·** JSTOR *(March 2017)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)* **Lim Swee Say** ([Chinese](/wiki/Simplified_Chinese_characters): 林瑞生; [pinyin](/wiki/Pinyin): *Lín Ruìshēng*; [Pe̍h-ōe-jī](/wiki/Pe%CC%8Dh-%C5%8De-j%C4%AB): *Lîm Sūi-seⁿ*; born 13 July 1954) is a Singaporean former politician who served as Secretary-General of the [National Trades Union Congress](/wiki/National_Trades_Union_Congress) between 2005 and 2015, [Minister for Manpower](/wiki/Ministry_of_Manpower_(Singapore)) between 2015 and 2018, [Minister in the Prime Minister's Office](/wiki/Prime_Minister%27s_Office_(Singapore)) between 2004 and 2015, [Second Minister for National Development](/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Development_(Singapore)) in 2004 and 2005, and [Minister for the Environment](/wiki/Ministry_of_Sustainability_and_the_Environment) between 2000 and 2004. A member of the governing [People's Action Party](/wiki/People%27s_Action_Party) (PAP), he was the [Member of Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_Singapore#Members_of_Parliament) (MP) for the Buona Vista division between 1997 and 2011 under various [group representation constituencies](/wiki/Group_representation_constituency) (GRCs),[a] and the Bedok division of [East Coast GRC](/wiki/East_Coast_Group_Representation_Constituency) between 2011 and 2020. Lim was appointed as a non-executive independent director in [Singtel](/wiki/Singtel) in 2021. ## Early life and career Lim was born to Teochews and educated at [Catholic High School](/wiki/Catholic_High_School_(Singapore)) and [National Junior College](/wiki/National_Junior_College) before graduating from [Loughborough University](/wiki/Loughborough_University) in 1976 with a first class honours degree in electronics, computer and systems engineering under a scholarship conferred by the [Singapore Armed Forces](/wiki/Singapore_Armed_Forces) (SAF) in 1973. He subsequently went on to complete a master's degree in management at [Stanford University](/wiki/Stanford_University) in 1991. Lim served as Chief Executive of the National Computer Board between 1986 and 1991, and later as chairman between 1994 and 1998. He also served as Deputy Managing Director at the [Economic Development Board](/wiki/Economic_Development_Board) (EDB) based in [New York City](/wiki/New_York_City) between 1991 and 1993, and later as managing director between 1994 and 1996. ## Political career Lim made his political debut in the [1997 general election](/wiki/1997_Singaporean_general_election) as part of a five-member PAP team contesting in [Tanjong Pagar GRC](/wiki/Tanjong_Pagar_Group_Representation_Constituency), led by Prime Minister [Lee Kuan Yew](/wiki/Lee_Kuan_Yew) and was elected in a walkover. He was on the PAP's team in [Holland–Bukit Panjang GRC](/wiki/Holland%E2%80%93Bukit_Panjang_Group_Representation_Constituency) at the [2001 general election](/wiki/2001_Singaporean_general_election), and in [Holland–Bukit Timah GRC](/wiki/Holland%E2%80%93Bukit_Timah_Group_Representation_Constituency) at the [2006 general election](/wiki/2006_Singaporean_general_election), and was elected unopposed on both occasions. At the [2011 general election](/wiki/2011_Singaporean_general_election), Lim stood in [East Coast GRC](/wiki/East_Coast_Group_Representation_Constituency), where the PAP's team defeated the team from the opposition [Workers' Party](/wiki/Workers%27_Party_of_Singapore) by 59,992 votes (54.8%) to 49,429 (45.2%). Lim served as Deputy Secretary-General of the [National Trades Union Congress](/wiki/National_Trades_Union_Congress) (NTUC) from 1997 to 1999. He also served on the Committee on Singapore's Competitiveness from 1997 to 1998, and chaired its Sub-committee on Manpower Development. In 1999, Lim was appointed as [Minister of State for Trade and Industry](/wiki/Ministry_of_Trade_and_Industry_(Singapore)) and [Minister of State for Information, Communications and the Arts](/wiki/Ministry_of_Information,_Communications_and_the_Arts). Lim was made a member of the PAP's [Central Executive Committee](/wiki/Central_Executive_Committee_(PAP)) in 1999 and served as the chairman of the party's [youth wing](/wiki/Young_PAP) between 2000 and 2004. Lim was made the Acting Minister for the Environment on 1 October 2000. He became a full minister of the [Cabinet](/wiki/Cabinet_of_Singapore) on 23 November 2001. ### Minister in Prime Minister's Office (2004–2015) On 12 August 2004, Lim was appointed a Minister in the Prime Minister's Office. He also served as the Second [Minister for National Development](/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Development_(Singapore)) from 12 August 2004 to 29 May 2006. In 2005, Lim became the Deputy Secretary-General of the NTUC for the second time (while continuing to serve concurrently as a Minister without portfolio in the Prime Minister's Office). In 2007, he was made the Secretary-General of the NTUC. In 2014, Lim appeared on Singapore's [Mediacorp Channel 8](/wiki/Mediacorp_Channel_8) episode "Hear Me Out", to respond to the criticisms against him and clarify himself on a few topics such as his Zorro costume, "Cheaper Better Faster", "Better, Betterer, Betterest", "Deaf Frog" and why Singapore implements [Progressive Wage Model](/wiki/Progressive_wage) instead of [minimum wage](/wiki/Minimum_wage). ### Minister for Manpower (2015–2018) On 4 May 2015, Lim relinquished his post of Minister in Prime Minister's Office and NTUC secretary-general (in line with the NTUC's retirement policies) and was appointed the Minister for Manpower. Lim retired from the cabinet on 1 May 2018, with his Manpower portfolio succeeded to [Josephine Teo](/wiki/Josephine_Teo). On the same day, he was appointed to NTUC as trustee of NTUC and chairman of NTUC Administration and Research Unit (ARU) Board of Trustees replacing his predecessor [Lim Boon Heng](/wiki/Lim_Boon_Heng). On 5 May, Lim was awarded the Distinguished Comrade of Labour during the May Day Awards ceremony. ### Retirement from politics In 2020, Lim announced that he would be retiring from politics, and not stand for the [2020 general election](/wiki/2020_Singaporean_general_election). In 2021, he was appointed as an independent director in Singtel. ## Personal life Lim married Elaine Cheong Siew Boon (born 1952) in 1981, introduced by a mutual friend. The couple had one daughter and one son. Cheong died on 6 July 2021, having had stage 4 cancer since 2017. He is a Roman Catholic and is an ethnic [Singaporean Chinese](/wiki/Chinese_Singaporeans) of [Teochew](/wiki/Teochew_people) descent. ## Notes - Lim Swee Say at cabinet.gov.sg - Lim Swee Say Archived 29 June 2017 at the [Wayback Machine](/wiki/Wayback_Machine) at parliament.gov.sg Political officesPreceded by[Lee Yock Suan](/wiki/Lee_Yock_Suan) **[Minister for the Environment](/wiki/Ministry_of_the_Environment_(Singapore))** 23 November 2001 – 11 August 2004 Acting: 1 October 2000 – 22 November 2001Succeeded by[Yaacob Ibrahim](/wiki/Yaacob_Ibrahim)***as Minister for the Environment and Water Resources*** **New office** **[Second Minister for National Development](/wiki/Ministry_of_National_Development_(Singapore))** 12 August 2004 – 30 September 2005**Position abolished** Preceded by[Tan Chuan-Jin](/wiki/Tan_Chuan-Jin) **[Minister for Manpower](/wiki/Ministry_of_Manpower_(Singapore))** 1 October 2015 – 30 April 2018Succeeded by[Josephine Teo](/wiki/Josephine_Teo)[Parliament of Singapore](/wiki/Parliament_of_Singapore)Preceded byPeter Sung **Member of Parliament for [Tanjong Pagar GRC](/wiki/Tanjong_Pagar_GRC) (Buona Vista)** 1997 – 2001**Ward abolished** **New constituency** **Member of Parliament for [Holland–Bukit Panjang GRC](/wiki/Holland%E2%80%93Bukit_Panjang_GRC) (Buona Vista)** 2001 – 2006**Constituency abolished** **New constituency** **Member of Parliament for [Holland–Bukit Timah GRC](/wiki/Holland%E2%80%93Bukit_Timah_GRC) (Buona Vista)** 2006 – 2011Succeeded by[Chan Chun Sing](/wiki/Chan_Chun_Sing)***as MP for Tanjong Pagar GRC (Buona Vista)*** Preceded by[S.
